title: How many seats will the New Patriotic Party win in Ghana's 2020 parliamentary elections?
possible_answers: A plurality of seats, but not a majority
Neither a majority nor a plurality
Parliamentary elections in Ghana will not take place in 2020
correct_answer: Neither a majority nor a plurality

https://www.bbc.com/pidgin/world-55226439 Early results favor NPP, but only <2M/31M have been counted.

Provided the elections take place as scheduled on 07 December 2020, there are two major factors to consider:
In the presidential elections, the NPP candidate Nana Akufo-Addo is the incumbent and has previously served as minister of foreign affairs before his first term. As the incumbent, he is likely to get re-elected, however, the contest in the 2016 election was so close (53.72% vs. 44.53%) that, according to an anecdote, "[t]he election results were announced on 9 December 2016 due to a delay of voting in two areas. At 19:51 local time, Mahama called Akufo-Addo to concede defeat. At 20:45, the Electoral Commission declared that Akufo-Addo had defeated Mahama in a single round."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Ghanaian_general_election Ghana obviously has a two-party system, where the other candidate was incumbent President John Mahama and got defeated in 2016, and is now going to tackle presidency once more. /Other candidates:
In 2016, "[o]ver 16 people filed with the election commission to run for president. However, 13 presidential candidates were disqualified due to incorrect filing procedures. The disqualified candidates included former first lady Nana Konadu Agyeman Rawlings, the president of the National Democratic Party. There was some controversy due to allegations that the candidates were disqualified for political reasons." After some litigation, seven candidates in total were allowed to run, five of which totaled a combined percentage of votes of less than 2% and thus did not influence the neck and neck race between Mahama and Akufo-Addo by a wide margin.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Ghanaian_general_election#Presidential_candidates In this year's presidential election, the preliminary list of applicants contained 17 names, twelve candidates are obviously finally admitted according to a list, whereas five other candidates apparently have been excluded.
https://en.wikipedia.orghttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Ghanaian_general_election#Final_list_of_Presidential_candidates All parties from 2016  have a presidential candidate running again, however, the following parties and candidates are new to the race in 2020 and their performance - alone and/or in total -  could be the feather that breaks the balance over the question, whether Akufo-Addo can again collect a majority in the presidential race.
Ghana Union Movement 	GUM 	Christian Kwabena Andrews
Ghana Freedom Party 	GFP 	Akua Donkor
Great Consolidated Popular Party 	GCPP 	Henry Herbert Lartey
All People's Congress 	APC 	Hassan Ayariga
Liberal Party of Ghana 	LPG 	Percival Kofi Akpaloo
Additionally, the only independent candidate is Alfred Kwame Asiedu Walker (2016: Jacob Osei Yeboah), and the candidates of Progressive People's Party (PPP) and People's National Convention (PNC) have altered. With regards to the parliamentary elections, as part of the 2020 General Elections and which take place simultaneously, the majority for Akufo-Addo's NPP has been even slimmer in 2016, so there is some kind of a political "halo-effect" of the president's person. The NPP with candidates for all 275 seat won only 52.48%. However, the NPP won 169 seats, which means it must have won most of its seat with a very narrow margin, and lost the rest to the NDC by a wide margin.
A different explanation is offered by the regional/district key of parliamentary seats, which has been established after the 2018 Ghanaian new regions referendum:
The NPP has its traditional strongholds in the presidential election in Ashanti and Greater Accra, the most populous regions, and thus won the most important constituencies, which brought along 44 vs. 3 seats and 21 vs. 13 seats respectively. Other strongholds for parliamentary seats for the NPP are Central (19 vs. 4), Eastern (28 vs. 5) and the newly established Western (13 vs. 4) and Bono (11 vs. 1).
In contrast, the 2016 strongholds of Mahamas's as a presidential candidate, Volta (subsequently split in two, Volta and Oti) carry 18 vs. zero and 7 vs. 1 seats only; Northern (subsequently split into Northern, North East and Savannah) 9 vs. 9 seats, 3 vs. 3 and 6 vs. 1 seats respectively for Muhama's NDC, probably as the constituencies there are less populous.
All other parties received *zero* parliamentary seats in total.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Ghanaian_general_election#By_region
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Ghanaian_new_regions_referendum
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Ghana#Composition_of_Parliament_after_the_2018_Ghanaian_new_regions_referendum As a conclusion, however close the presidential race will be and whatever effect the additional parties and candidates there may have on the percentage of votes for the NPP's candidate Akufo-Addo (he may end up just below 50% or majority) the new arrangement of electoral districts after 2018 indicates, that the NPP only has to be at least at the same outcome as in the 2016 elections in their own strongholds and not too much worse in the NDC's strongholds to keep their majority in the 2020 elections. All other electoral districts play a minor role and are not critical for the balance of power, as they are less populous and thus are assigned fewer seats. Keeping Ashanti and expanding seats in  Greater Accra will be half the way to a NPP majority. /Different methods of voter suppression, disenfranchisement skew the election results towards the larger parties in general and towards the NPP in particular:
[i] The "single-member constituencies using first-past-the-post voting" favor the candidates of either the NPP or the NDC (which are the only parties to have candidates for all 275 constituencies), candidates of all other smaller parties have virtually no chance of winning one of the seats.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Ghanaian_general_election#Electoral_system
[ii] As the numerous lawsuits ahead of both 2016 and 2020 candidate filings show, the Electoral Commission appears to be not completely impartial: if 13 candidates have been disqualified for the presidential election in 2016 alone, it is highly likely that either the filing process is very complicated or larded with additional hurdles, or candidates with less resources, party background or independents who could endanger the established two-party system are kept from being eligible intentionally, even for the parliamentary election.
[iii]The 2018 Ghanaian new regions referendum, which happened under the NPP government is likely to further skew the assignment of seats in the parliament in the NPP's favor as it was an opportunity to crop and tailor electoral districts along demographic and ethnic edges. Three factors could have played a role in the decision for this referendum: [a] African countries tend to have a high share of under-age non voters, which I suppose tend to live in rural areas predominantly. As they bring no advantage in election terms, they are likely excluded from the governing party's districts. [b] urbanization and interior migration of labor force towards larger cities (the capital Accra in this case) renders it likely that the these metropolitan areas are now represented more than proportionately. [c] population growth in total (latest census figures date back to 2010) is likely inhomogeneous regionally, which would mean a shift of the electoral over time.
I assume that the NPP will have designed the new districts with respect to all these factors, so that the party will not be worse-off in 2020 than in 2016 with regards to parliamentary seats. All of this suggests that the NPP will win a number of seats in the range of 160 to 175, which would again mean a majority.

There's no similarity between 2020 elections of US and Ghana – Oppong Nkrumah - GhanaWeb
https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/There-s-no-similarity-between-2020-elections-of-US-and-Ghana-Oppong-Nkrumah-1095748
Thu, 29 Oct 2020 08:24:42 GMT  “While Mr Biden was not rejected at the polls by voters in 2016, Mr Mahama was massively rejected by Ghanaian voters.” “While Mr Biden’s running mate Senator Harris is an accomplished senator who has added a spark to his candidature, same cannot be said of the NDC.” “There is no similarity between the elections in the US and elections in Ghana. Their current President was a businessman who became a politician. Our current President, on the other hand, is an astute lawyer and politician.” “Their President is contesting a former Vice President and not a President who was voted out of power. For ours, Mr. Mahama was voted out of power because he was a President who supervised hunger, unemployment, erratic power supply and economic hardship. It is not the same with Joe Biden. So there is a vast difference in the politics of the two countries,” he said.  “In 2016 there was a similar myth that you cannot win the Presidency if you are not named John. Nana Addo beat John Mahama at the time despite this claim. It is about your hard work and not such comparisons.” He concluded. What a shade.

For the NPP to lose it's majority it has to lose a net 32 seats. 
Ghana has had relatively stable elections for nearly 30 years. 
Since there were only two winners last time, I'm discounting the plurality option. 
Elections could be counted on, if not for COVID-19. 
Ghana uses "First Pass The Post" system for parliamentary elections, in which according to Wikipedia:  It is more likely that a single party will hold a majority of legislative seats.
Much more research is needed.

Elections (percentage of the vote):
- 1996: 39.7%
- 2000: 56.9%
- 2004: 52.4%
- 2008: 49.8%
- 2012: 47.7%
- 2016: 53.7% Parliamentary seats: 
- 1996: 61 / 200 (m)
- 2000: 99 / 200 (P & ¬M)
- 2004: 128 / 230 (M)
- 2008: 107 / 230 (m)
- 2012: 123 / 275 (m)
- 2016: 169 / 275 (M) Base rate: 
- Plurality but not majority = 1/6 
- minority = 3/6
- Majority = 2/6  I'm picking a 20% that it will be delayed out of no principled reason, but note that the elections are pretty close to the end of the year, and Ghana has delayed elections before. Further, as the number of seats has increased and the influence of smaller parties decreased, a plurality but not a majority has become more implausible. Further, the two presidential candidates have stood against each other before, with a tally of 1:1  Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Ghanaian_general_election (one can click to view the previous elections).
